thread.title: Go ahead, water your lawn
thread.title_full: Go ahead, water your lawn | Breaking News & Headlines

author: Graham Finley
title: Go ahead, water your lawn
text:
Have you watered your yard lately? You probably should.
Such a recommendation could possibly seem irresponsible in the face of the California drought, but the recent rush to slash urban landscape water use, and in the procedure let trees, shrubs and lawns decline or die, is shortsighted, foolish, expensive and, most tragic of all, unnecessary.
It really is shortsighted since the urban landscape delivers quite a few positive aspects and amenities that add immeasurably to the quality of our lives. To list just a few, trees, shrubs and lawns present: beauty and ornament shade and energy savings in heating and cooling privacy food wildlife habitat oxygen jobs carbon sequestration to enable mitigate international warming rain capture for dust and erosion manage enhanced home values recreational opportunities cultural and historic worth and even psychological effectively-being.
A single Canadian study this year showed that possessing ten extra trees on a city block improves wellness perception (or the feeling of wellness) in approaches comparable to an improve in annual personal income of $10,000, moving to a neighborhood with a $10,000 larger median income, or being seven years younger.
It is foolish since urban landscape irrigation accounts for such a tiny aspect of the water utilized in California. Although it really is accurate that 50% of residential water use takes spot outdoors, information show that less than 9% of the developed water employed in California ends up on the urban landscape. So if we by no means watered yet another tree, shrub, ground cover, lawn or flower once again in California, the state would save at the most 9% of its water.
It really is high-priced because, as landscapes go dry, the direct charges could be massive to handle and clean up dead and dying trees, retrofit irrigation systems and replant landscapes. Also, a lot of indirect or hidden costs are associated with this approach, such as lawsuits more than home damage and human injury or even death from failing trees, improved fire danger and, in the extended-term, lost jobs and reduced financial activity for gardeners and landscapers.
It is tragic because study at the University of California over the final 30 years shows that through acceptable landscape water management &#8212 the proper amount, at the correct time &#8212 we can cut down water use 30% or far more. We could thus meet most of the mandated cutback goals yet still retain our trees, shrubs, ground covers and, yes, even some location of lawn. It is definitely unnecessary to let them go brown and die. It’s also unnecessary to make wholesale alterations in our landscape palette, ripping out established flora and replanting with &#8220drought tolerant&#8221 plants, to save water. Our research has shown that most of our trees, shrubs and ground covers in California if planted, established, and cared for and irrigated adequately are currently pretty drought tolerant.
The poorly crafted landscape water conservation guidelines, such as watering only two days a week and/or only 15 minutes of run time per station, are horticulturally unsound, because they do not take into account sprinkler precipitation prices, soil sorts, soil water-holding capacity, plant kind or rooting depth, among other components. The no-water-on-lawn-medians decree takes the prize for ignorance, though, because most cities have stopped watering their medians totally with no making provisions for the trees. As the lawns go brown, the trees are declining and dying.
Lawns have of course been particularly singled out as water-wasting culprits and borne the brunt of the anti-water scorn &#8212 but this, too, is unscientific. They account for only about three% to 5% of all the water used in California. And our analysis has shown that warm-season grasses want 20% much less water than tall fescue, the most popular lawn grass thus, considerable savings can be attained without doing away with lawns completely and alternatively simply altering them from tall fescue to a warm-season grass.
Replacing lawns with artificial turf isn’t a fantastic idea turf, in fact, has significant environmental drawbacks, amongst them enhanced surface temperatures, heat collection and retention, lack of carbon sequestration, no absorption of greenhouse gases, and enhanced water run-off &#8212 as nicely as the fact that turf is plastic-primarily based and therefore a petroleum product.
Official but unacknowledged state policy for the last decade has been to help water demand for future growth mainly by attempting to wring out savings via urban landscape water conservation. But with the state projected to add 10 million individuals by 2025, and with landscape irrigation accounting for such a small portion of the water utilised in the state, any sixth-grader can do the math and see that this is a nonsensical method.
What’s the policymakers’ agenda here? The approach is not so considerably to reach substantial statewide water savings &#8212 due to the fact there basically isn’t that substantially to save &#8212 but rather to put the screws to home owners so they will really feel inconvenienced and, hence, be much more prepared to support future controversial state water projects, like the gigantic twin tunnels below the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.
Urban dwellers and property owners make effortless targets simply because there is no a single unified voice with abundant sources that can advocate for them. But it really is misguided to single out urban landscape water use. Even in this historic drought, landscape and specifically trees are worth obtaining and saving. We can have our landscape &#8212 and nevertheless save water.
Donald R. Hodel and Dennis R. Pittenger each have a lot more than 30 years of encounter as UC Cooperative Extension advisors who specialize in the selection and management of trees and landscape plants, including irrigation.
